trans-unit.source: Represents a control that displays hierarchical data in a tree structure that has items that can expand and collapse.
<xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> is an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>, which means it can contain a collection of objects of any type (such as string, image, or panel).
For more information, see the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl> class.
The following illustration shows a simple <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView>.
![TreeView illustration](~/add/media/treeviewillustration.JPG "TreeView illustration")

The contents of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> are <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem> controls that can contain rich content, such as <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Button> and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Image> controls.
A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem> can contain one or more <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem> objects as its descendants.
A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> is defined as a hierarchy of <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem> objects.
A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> can populate its tree by binding to a data source and using <xref:System.Windows.HierarchicalDataTemplate> objects.
Examples of data sources include <xref:System.Windows.Data.XmlDataProvider> and <xref:System.Collections.ObjectModel.ObservableCollection%601> objects.
Displaying a large number of items may cause performance issues.
See [Optimizing Performance: Controls](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/optimizing-performance-controls.md) for more information.

To improve the performance of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView>, see [How to: Improve the Performance of a TreeView](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/how-to-improve-the-performance-of-a-treeview.md).
For more information about the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> control, see the [TreeView Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/treeview-overview.md).
A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> has a limited number of levels.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual>.
Customizing the TreeView Control
To apply the same property settings to multiple <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> controls, use the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Style%2A> property.
You can modify the default <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> to give the control a unique appearance.

For more information about creating a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate>, see [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/customizing-the-appearance-of-an-existing-control.md).
To see the parts and states that are specific to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView>, see [TreeView Styles and Templates](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/treeview-styles-and-templates.md).
Dependency properties for this control might be set by the controlâ€™s default style.
If a property is set by a default style, the property might change from its default value when the control appears in the application.
The default style is determined by which desktop theme is used when the application is running.
For more information, see [Default WPF Themes](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=158252).
Setting a visual property will only have an effect if that property is both present in <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> control's default template and is set by using a .

You can find a list of visual properties in the "Changing the Visual Structure of a Control" section in [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/customizing-the-appearance-of-an-existing-control.md).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref> class.
Expands the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem"></xref> control and all its child <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem"></xref> elements.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem"></xref> to expand.
`true` if the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem"></xref> and all its child elements were expanded; otherwise, `false`.
Creates a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem"></xref> to use to display content.
A new <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem"></xref> to use as a container for content.
Gets whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref> can scroll.
Always returns `true` because the control has a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.ScrollViewer"></xref> in its style.
Determines whether the specified item is its own container or can be its own container.
The object to evaluate.
`true` if item is a ; otherwise, `false`.
Defines an <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.Peers.AutomationPeer"></xref> for the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref> control.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.Peers.TreeViewAutomationPeer"></xref> for the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref> control.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.UIElement.GotFocus"></xref> routed event.
The data for the event.

Provides class handling for an <xref href="System.Windows.ContentElement.IsKeyboardFocusWithinChanged"></xref> event when the keyboard focus changes for a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref>.
The event data.

Provides class handling for an <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.ItemContainerGenerator.ItemsChanged"></xref> event that occurs when there is a change in the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl.Items"></xref> collection.
The event data.
Provides class handling for the <xref href="System.Windows.UIElement.KeyDown"></xref> event for a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref>.
This implementation sets <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> to `true` if one of the following keys is pressed together with the CTRL key:
The event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItemChanged"></xref> event when the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItem"></xref> property value changes.

The event data that the parameter `e` provides contains an <xref:System.Windows.DependencyPropertyChangedEventArgs.OldValue%2A?displayProperty=fullName> and a <xref:System.Windows.Ink.PropertyDataChangedEventArgs.NewValue%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.

The <xref:System.Windows.DependencyPropertyChangedEventArgs.OldValue%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is set to the item that was previously selected, or is set to `null` if there is no previously selected item.
Similarly, the <xref:System.Windows.Ink.PropertyDataChangedEventArgs.NewValue%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is set to the newly selected item, or is set to `null` if no new item is selected.
Provides the item that was previously selected and the item that is currently selected for the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItemChanged"></xref> event.
Gets the selected item in a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItem%2A> property on the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> control is a read-only property and is set to an item when the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem.IsSelected%2A> property value of the item <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> is set to `true`.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None
The selected object in the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref>, or `null` if no item is selected.
The default value is `null`.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItem"></xref> changes.
Routed Event Information
Identifier Field
Routing Strategy
Bubbling
Delegate
XAML Attribute Usage
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItemChanged"></xref> routed event.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItem"></xref> dependency property.

Gets the value of the property that is the specified by <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValuePath"></xref> for the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItem"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValuePath%2A> property specifies the path to the property that is used to determine the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValue%2A> property.
For example, assume that a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> is bound to a collection of objects of type `Employee`, which has two properties called `EmployeeName` and `EnployeeNumber`.

You can use a <xref:System.Windows.HierarchicalDataTemplate> to display the value of `EmployeeName` in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> and set <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValuePath%2A> to `"EmployeeNumber"` to have <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValue%2A> return the value of `EmployeeNumber`.
The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValue%2A> property is a read-only property.

To change the value of a selected item in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView>, use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItem%2A> property to access the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeViewItem>.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None

The value of the property that is specified by the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValuePath"></xref> for the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItem"></xref>, or `null` if no item is selected.
The default value is `null`.

Gets or sets the path that is used to get the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValue"></xref> of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedItem"></xref> in a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValuePath%2A> property specifies the path to the property that is used to determine the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValue%2A> property.
For example, assume that a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> is bound to a collection of objects of type `Employee`, which has two properties called `EmployeeName` and `EnployeeNumber`.

You can use a <xref:System.Windows.HierarchicalDataTemplate> to display the value of `EmployeeName` in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView> and set <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValuePath%2A> to `"EmployeeNumber"` to have <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValue%2A> return the value of `EmployeeNumber`.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None
A string that contains the path that is used to get the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValue"></xref>.
The default value is `String.Empty`.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValuePath"></xref> dependency property.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TreeView.SelectedValue"></xref> dependency property.
